text: Lovelock's theorem of general relativity says that from a local gravitational action which contains only second derivatives of the four-dimensional spacetime metric, then the only possible equations of motion are the Einstein field equations. The theorem was described by British physicist David Lovelock in 1971. ==Statement== In four dimensional space, any tensor A^{\mu u} whose components are function of metric tensor g^{\mu u} and its first and second derivatives (but linear in the second derivatives of g^{\mu u}), and also symmetric and divergenceless, then field equation in vacuum A^{\mu u}=0, then only possible form of A^{\mu u} is :A^{\mu u}=a G^{\mu u}+b g^{\mu u} where a and b are just simple constant numbers and G^{\mu u} is the Einstein tensor. The only possible second-order Euler–Lagrange expression obtainable in a four-dimensional space from a scalar density of the form \mathcal{L}=\mathcal{L}(g_{\mu u}) is E^{\mu u} = \alpha \sqrt{-g} \left[R^{\mu u} - \frac{1}{2} g^{\mu u} R \right] + \lambda \sqrt{-g} g^{\mu u} ==Consequences== Lovelock's theorem means that if we want to modify the Einstein field equations, then we have five options. * Add other fields rather than the metric tensor * Use more or less than four spacetime dimensions * Add more than second order derivatives of the metric * Non- locality, e.g. for example the inverse d'Alembertian * Emergence – the idea that the field equations don't come from the action. ==See also== * Lovelock theory of gravity * Vermeil's theorem ==References== Category:General relativity Category:Theorems in general relativity
title: Lovelock's theorem
